Abraham Lincoln: He was the first U.S. president to be assassinated.
Marilyn Monroe: In 1953, the actress starred in the romantic comedy "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes" and sang the iconic song "Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend".
Elvis Presley: In 1956, a musician from Tupelo, Mississippi, became the first person to have three songs in the Billboard Top 5 at the same time.
Albert Einstein: He was offered the presidency of Israel in 1952, but declined the offer.
Oprah Winfrey: In 1986, they became the first African American woman to host a nationally syndicated talk show.
Nelson Mandela: In 1994, the first black president of South Africa was elected after spending 27 years in prison.
John Lennon: In 1975, he released a solo album that featured no musical instruments.
Hillary Clinton: In 2000, she became the first female senator to be elected from the state of New York.
Steven Spielberg: He was the first director to have three films gross over $1 billion at the box office.
George Lucas: The creator of the Star Wars franchise was once rejected from the University of Southern California School of Cinematic Arts.
J.K. Rowling: The author of the Harry Potter series is the first person to become a billionaire by writing books.
Queen Elizabeth II: The longest-reigning monarch in British history is a female.
Bill Gates: The world's second-richest person has donated over $35 billion to charity.
Barack Obama: He was the first African-American president of the Harvard Law Review.
Miley Cyrus: In 2013, they became the first artist to have seven songs from the same album chart on the Billboard Hot 100 at the same time.
Justin Bieber: In 2010, a then-16-year-old Canadian singer became the first artist to have seven songs from a debut album chart on the Billboard Hot 100.
Taylor Swift: In 2008, the artist won a Grammy Award for Album of the Year, becoming the youngest artist to ever win the award.
Katy Perry: In 2011, she became the first artist to have five songs from the same album reach number one on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.
Beyonce: In 2003, the singer released a single that topped the Billboard Hot 100 chart for eleven consecutive weeks.
Jennifer Lopez: She was the first actress to have a number one movie and album in the same week.
Madonna: In 1985, the artist released a single that reached number one on the Billboard Hot 100 chart without ever appearing on an album.
Michael Jackson: In 1982, the artist released a single that became the first music video to be aired on MTV.
Kanye West: In 2005, they won a Grammy for Best Rap Song for their single "Jesus Walks".
Drake: The artist known as Drake was the first artist to have all of their top 10 singles on the Billboard Hot 100 chart simultaneously.
Adele: In 2011, the singer won an Academy Award for Best Original Song for the theme song to the James Bond film Skyfall.
Rihanna: She was the first female artist to have 14 number one singles on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.
Justin Timberlake: He was a cast member of the popular television show "The Mickey Mouse Club" from 1993 to 1995.
Eminem: In 2002, the artist released an album that was the fastest-selling rap album in history, selling over 1.76 million copies in its first week.
Lady Gaga: In 2008, the artist released an album of all acoustic music under the pseudonym "Stefani Germanotta."
Ed Sheeran: Ed Sheeran was the first artist to have two singles debut in the top 10 of the Billboard Hot 100 chart simultaneously.
Bob Dylan: In 1965, the artist released a chart-topping single that was the first rock song to ever win a Grammy Award.
Bruce Springsteen: He was born in the United States but grew up in Freehold, New Jersey, a small town about 50 miles south of New York City.
David Bowie: In 1972, the artist released a single under the pseudonym Arnold Corns, which was the first time he used a stage name.
Whitney Houston: In 1992, the singer released a single that became the first song by a female artist to debut at number one on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.
Mariah Carey: In 1990, Mariah Carey wrote and produced a song for the soundtrack of the movie "The Prince of Egypt" which went on to win a Grammy Award.
Celine Dion: The singer has sold over 200 million albums worldwide, making her one of the best-selling artists of all time.
Barbra Streisand: In 1969, the singer became the first woman to win the Grammy Award for Album of the Year.
Tom Hanks: He was the first actor to have two back-to-back films gross over $100 million domestically in the same year.
George Clooney: He was the first male spokesperson for Nespresso.
Angelina Jolie: They are the first recipient of the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.
Brad Pitt: In 1995, the actor starred in a science fiction film that was the first to use computer-generated imagery to create a photorealistic world.
Lionel Messi: He is the only player in history to win six Ballon d'Or awards.
Cristiano Ronaldo: He is the most followed person on Instagram, with over 200 million followers.
Warren Buffett: The world's third-richest person is an avid bridge player and has won several tournaments.
Mark Zuckerberg: In 2010, the founder of Facebook donated $100 million to the Newark Public School System.
Jeff Bezos: The founder of Amazon is the world's first centi-billionaire, with a net worth of over $100 billion.
Vladimir Putin: The current president of Russia was once a KGB agent in East Germany.
Dalai Lama: The current spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism is the 14th reincarnation of a lineage of spiritual leaders that dates back to the 13th century.
Margaret Thatcher: She was the first female Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
Steve Jobs: In 1976, the co-founder of Apple Inc. was responsible for creating the first commercial personal computer.
Michael Jordan: In 1984, the athlete was drafted by the Chicago Bulls with the third overall pick in the NBA Draft.
LeBron James: In 2018, the basketball player became the first African-American to own a professional sports franchise in the United States.
Tiger Woods: In 1997, a then 21-year-old golfer became the youngest ever to win the Masters Tournament.
Roger Federer: He is the only male tennis player in history to have won 20 Grand Slam singles titles.
Lionel Richie: In 1983, the singer won a Grammy Award for Best Male Pop Vocal Performance for the song "Truly".
Paul McCartney: He was the first musician to be knighted for his contributions to music.
Elton John: In 1997, he became the first major artist to perform a concert in the newly independent country of Belarus.
Kim Kardashian: In 2014, the reality star donated $200,000 to a children's hospital in Los Angeles.
David Beckham: He was the first English player to win league titles in four countries.
Michael Phelps: The most decorated Olympian of all time has won 28 Olympic medals, 23 of which are gold.
Serena Williams: In 2002, the winner of the Australian Open was the first African American woman to win a Grand Slam singles title in the Open Era.
Andy Murray: In 2016, the first British tennis player in 77 years won a singles gold medal at the Olympic Games.
Kobe Bryant: In 1996, the then 18-year-old was the first guard ever drafted out of high school.
Elon Musk: The founder of Tesla, SpaceX, and The Boring Company is the longest-serving CEO of any automotive company in the world.
Joe Biden: He was the sixth-youngest U.S. Senator in history when he was first elected in 1972.
In 2008, the actor was named one of Time Magazine's 100 Most Influential People in the World.
Will Smith: The actor who played the Fresh Prince of Bel-Air was the first rapper to have a #1 hit on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.
Billie Eilish: At the age of 14, they became the youngest artist to write and record a James Bond theme song.
Britney Spears: In 1998, she became the youngest recording artist to have a number one single on the Billboard Hot 100 chart with her debut single "Baby One More Time".
Bruce Willis: He was once a security guard at a nuclear power plant.
Cardi B: In 2018, a rapper became the first female artist to have five simultaneous top 10 singles on the Billboard Hot 100 chart.
Cher: In 1965, they released a single called "Ringo, I Love You" under the name Bonnie Jo Mason.
Chris Evans: He was born in Boston, Massachusetts and is the oldest of three children.
Donald Trump: In 2016, the individual who would become the 45th President of the United States was the first major-party nominee in over 40 years to not release their tax returns.
Dua Lipa: In 2020, the singer won five awards at the Brit Awards, making them the most awarded artist in a single night in the history of the awards.
Ellen Degeneres: In 1997, the star of a popular sitcom became the first lead character to come out as gay on primetime television.
Harrison Ford: He was a carpenter before becoming an actor.
Harry Styles: He was the first member of One Direction to have a solo number one single on the UK Singles Chart.
Howard Stern: In 1986, the radio personality was the first to be inducted into the National Radio Hall of Fame.
Jennifer Aniston: She was the first person to win a Primetime Emmy, Golden Globe, and Screen Actors Guild Award for the same role.
Jennifer Lawrence: She was the highest-paid actress in the world in 2015 and 2016.
Jerry Seinfeld: The actor and comedian was once a volunteer firefighter in his hometown of Massapequa, New York.
Johnny Depp: In 2003, the actor was named the Sexiest Man Alive by People magazine.
Julia Roberts: In 1990, she was the first actress to ever be paid $20 million for a single movie role.
Keanu Reeves: In 1991, he donated $80,000 to the Canadian Actors' Fund.
Kevin Hart: In 2013, the actor became the first comedian to sell out an NFL stadium, performing to over 50,000 people at Lincoln Financial Field in Philadelphia.
Leonardo DiCaprio: He was the first actor born in the 1980s to have been nominated for the Academy Award for Best Actor.
Mel Gibson: In 1995, he directed, produced, and starred in the Academy Award-winning film Braveheart.
Robert De Niro: He was the first actor to win an Academy Award for playing a comic book character, for his role as Max Cady in the 1991 film Cape Fear.
Sandra Bullock: In 1996, she was named the highest-paid actress in Hollywood, earning $17 million for her role in the film Speed.
Simon Cowell: He was once a judge on the UK version of Pop Idol, which was the show that launched the career of pop star, Kelly Clarkson.
